description: The screenshot displays a standard Windows XP desktop. The mouse cursor hovers over the "Start" button located on the left side of the taskbar. The taskbar also houses the "Recycle Bin" icon on the right side, along with system tray icons for network connectivity, audio, and the current time (10:56 AM).

The screenshot shows the Windows XP "Start" menu open, covering the "Start" button. The mouse cursor hovers over the "Start" button, which is partially obscured by the open menu. The "All Programs" arrow within the Start menu is highlighted, indicating the mouse cursor hovered over it before moving to its current position.
The screenshot shows the Windows XP desktop with the "Start" menu open. The mouse cursor is now hovering over the "Control Panel" option within the Start menu.

The screenshot displays the Windows XP "Start" menu with the cursor hovering over the "Control Panel" option. A yellow tooltip box describes the Control Panel as providing "options for you to customize the appearance and functionality of your computer, add or remove programs, and set up network connections and user accounts."
The screenshot shows the Windows XP desktop with the "Start" menu open. The mouse cursor is no longer hovering over the "Control Panel" option, and the yellow tooltip box is no longer visible.

The screenshot displays the Windows XP desktop with the "Start" menu open. The mouse cursor is hovering over the "Control Panel" option in the Start menu.  The yellow tooltip box describing the Control Panel is no longer visible.
The screenshot shows the Windows XP desktop with the "Start" menu visible. The "Control Panel" option is no longer highlighted, and the yellow tooltip box is no longer present.

The screenshot shows the Windows XP desktop with the "Start" button visible in the bottom left corner. The mouse cursor, displaying an hourglass icon, is positioned in the center of the screen. The yellow tooltip box previously describing the Control Panel is no longer visible.

The screenshot shows the Windows XP desktop background, featuring a tropical beach scene. The "Start" menu is visible in the bottom left corner.  Missing is the "Start" menu tooltip box previously present. A new window titled "Control Panel" is now visible, expanded to nearly the full size of the screen.

The screenshot shows an open window titled "Control Panel" which occupies the top portion of the screen. The rest of the screen is grey. The "Start" menu is not visible. 

Missing UI Elements:
- The "Start" menu with the cursor hovering over the "Control Panel" option is no longer visible.
- The yellow tooltip box describing the Control Panel is gone.

New UI Elements:
- A window titled "Control Panel" is now visible.

The screenshot displays the Windows XP Control Panel window. The window displays the "Pick a category" view with various system icons and their corresponding labels. 

The "Start" menu is no longer visible. 

The yellow tooltip box describing the Control Panel is no longer visible.

The screenshot displays the Windows XP Control Panel window in "Category View". The "Control Panel" taskbar button is highlighted. The yellow tooltip box previously visible in the initial state is no longer present.
The screenshot displays the Windows XP Control Panel window in Category view. The previously described tooltip is no longer visible.
The screenshot displays the Windows XP Control Panel window in "Category View". The previously described tooltip is no longer visible.

The screenshot displays the Windows XP Control Panel window. The window occupies the majority of the screen and displays a list of icons and their corresponding labels, categorized as "Pick a category". The available categories are: "Appearance and Themes", "Network and Internet Connections", "Add or Remove Programs", "Sounds, Speech, and Audio Devices", "Performance and Maintenance", "Printers and Other Hardware", "User Accounts", "Date, Time, Language, and Regional Options", "Accessibility Options", and "Security Center". 

The previously described "Start" menu and its tooltip are no longer visible.

The screenshot displays the Windows XP Control Panel window. The window displays various category icons, including "Appearance and Themes," "Network and Internet Connections," "Add or Remove Programs," "Sounds, Speech, and Audio Devices," "Performance and Maintenance," "Printers and Other Hardware," "User Accounts," "Date, Time, Language, and Regional Options," "Accessibility Options," and "Security Center." 

The previously described "Start" menu and tooltip box are no longer visible.

The screenshot displays the Windows XP Control Panel window. The window is titled "Control Panel" and the main section is titled "Pick a category".  The previously present tooltip box describing the Control Panel is no longer visible.

The screenshot displays the Windows XP Control Panel in Category View. The mouse cursor hovers over the "Appearance and Themes" category, highlighting it and revealing a description box. The description reads: "Change the appearance of desktop items, apply a theme or screen saver to your computer, or customize the Start menu and taskbar." 

This category provides access to settings related to the visual customization of the Windows environment, including options for the screen saver, themes, and Start menu.

The screenshot displays the Windows XP Control Panel in Category View.  The "Appearance and Themes" category is no longer highlighted. The description box previously visible below the cursor is no longer present.

The screenshot shows the Windows XP Control Panel window. The window is in "Classic View", displaying a list of available control panel icons.  The previously described "Appearance and Themes" category and its description box are no longer visible. The mouse cursor is now an arrow located in the center of the window.

The screenshot shows the Windows XP Control Panel in Category View. The "Appearance and Themes" category is now open, revealing a list of tasks. The mouse cursor is hovering over the "Change the computer's theme" task.

Missing UI Elements:
- The description box that was previously visible when hovering over the "Appearance and Themes" category is no longer present.
The screenshot shows the Windows XP Control Panel in Category View. The "Appearance and Themes" category is no longer highlighted. The mouse cursor is not visible.
The screenshot shows the Windows XP Control Panel in Category View. The "Appearance and Themes" category is no longer highlighted. The mouse cursor is no longer visible.
The screenshot shows the Windows XP Control Panel in Category View. The "Appearance and Themes" category is no longer highlighted. The mouse cursor is not visible.
The screenshot displays the Windows XP Control Panel in Category View. The "Appearance and Themes" category is no longer highlighted. The mouse cursor is not visible.

The screenshot shows the Windows XP Control Panel in Category View. The "Appearance and Themes" category is no longer highlighted. The description box previously visible under the mouse cursor is gone.

The screenshot shows the Windows XP Control Panel in Category View. The "Appearance and Themes" category is no longer highlighted. The mouse cursor is now hovering over the "Choose a screen saver" task, highlighting it.

The screenshot displays the "Appearance and Themes" category within the Windows XP Control Panel. The mouse cursor hovers over the "Display" Control Panel icon, indicating the user's intent to select this option. 

The left pane presents two main sections: "See Also" and "Troubleshooters." "See Also" offers shortcuts to related settings: "Fonts," "Mouse Pointers," "High Contrast," and "User Account Picture." "Troubleshooters" provides access to diagnostic tools for "Display" and "Sound" issues.

The right pane, titled "Appearance and Themes," features two sections. The top section, "Pick a task...," lists common actions: "Change the computer's theme," "Change the desktop background," "Choose a screen saver," and "Change the screen resolution." 

The bottom section, "or pick a Control Panel icon," displays shortcuts to specific Control Panel applets: "Display," "Folder Options," and "Taskbar and Start Menu."
The screenshot shows the "Appearance and Themes" category within the Windows XP Control Panel. The mouse cursor is positioned over the "Display" Control Panel icon.

The screenshot shows the Windows XP desktop with the "Display Properties" window open. The window is blank, indicating an active process, as signified by the hourglass mouse cursor. 

The following elements are missing:
- The content of the right pane of the "Appearance and Themes" Control Panel window, including the "Pick a task..." and "or pick a Control Panel icon" sections, is no longer visible.

The screenshot shows the Windows XP "Display Properties" window overlayed on the "Appearance and Themes" Control Panel. 

New UI Elements:
- The "Display Properties" window is now visible. This window has the title bar "Display Properties" and contains a sample window displaying the "Active Window" and "Window Text" elements. 

Missing UI Elements:
- The mouse cursor is no longer hovering over the "Display" Control Panel icon.

The screenshot shows the "Display Properties" window open and in focus, with the "Screen Saver" tab selected.  This window was not present in the initial description. The mouse cursor now rests on the lower right corner of an empty preview window labeled "Active Window".  The previously described "Display" icon in the Control Panel is no longer highlighted.

The screenshot shows the Windows XP "Display Properties" window, specifically the "Themes" tab. The most prominent change is a new, smaller window titled "Active Window" is layered over the "Display Properties" window. This smaller window contains a text field displaying "Window Text" and a minimized view of a beach scene with a green recycle bin icon. The mouse cursor is hovering over the minimized view within the "Active Window".

The screenshot displays the "Display Properties" window in Windows XP, specifically the "Themes" tab. 

At the top, a tabbed interface presents options for "Themes," "Desktop," "Screen Saver," "Appearance," and "Settings," allowing users to customize various aspects of the display. The currently selected "Themes" tab is highlighted.

A dropdown menu labeled "Theme:" allows users to choose from available visual themes. The currently selected theme is "Windows XP (Modified)."

Below the theme selection, a preview window labeled "Sample:" showcases the selected theme's appearance, including the desktop background, window borders, and icon styles.

Three buttons are located to the right of the theme selection:
- "Save As...": Allows users to save a customized theme under a new name.
- "Delete": Enables users to remove a previously saved custom theme. 

At the bottom of the window, three standard buttons are visible:
- "OK": Confirms changes and closes the window.
- "Cancel": Discards any modifications and closes the window.
- "Apply": Applies the selected changes without closing the window.

The screenshot shows the "Display Properties" window, specifically the "Screen Saver" tab. 

Content Changes:
- The "Screen Saver" tab is now highlighted instead of the "Themes" tab. 

Missing UI Elements:
- The dropdown menu labeled "Theme:" and the "Sample:" preview window are no longer present.
- The buttons "Save As..." and "Delete" are not visible.

The screenshot shows the "Display Properties" window, specifically the "Screen Saver" tab is now selected. 

The "Screen Saver" dropdown menu shows "Windows XP" is selected. The "Wait" time is set to "10" minutes. The checkbox for "On resume, password protect" is unchecked. 

The "Delete" button is not present in the screenshot.

The screenshot shows the "Display Properties" window open with the "Screen Saver" tab selected. 

The dropdown menu labeled "Screen saver:" is set to "Windows XP". The "Wait:" time is set to "10" minutes, and the checkbox for "On resume, password protect" is unchecked. 

The "Delete" button is not present in this screenshot.

The screenshot displays the "Display Properties" window, specifically the "Screen Saver" tab, within the Windows XP operating system. 

The "Screen Saver" dropdown menu currently displays "Windows XP" as the selected screensaver. To the right, a "Settings" button allows for customization of the chosen screensaver.  Below, the "Wait" field, set to "10" minutes by default, dictates the idle time before the screensaver activates.  A checkbox labeled "On resume, password protect" enables password protection upon the user's return. 

Further down, the "Monitor power" section provides a "Power..." button. This button, when clicked, opens the "Power Options Properties" window, granting access to power management settings for the monitor and system. 

At the bottom of the window, standard "OK", "Cancel", and "Apply" buttons are visible. These buttons respectively accept changes, discard modifications, and immediately apply alterations without closing the window.

The screenshot shows the "Display Properties" window with the "Screen Saver" tab open. The most noticeable change is in the "Screen saver" dropdown menu where "None" is now selected instead of "Windows XP".

The screenshot shows the "Display Properties" window with the "Screen Saver" tab open. 

Content Changes:
- The "Screen Saver" dropdown menu now displays "[None]" as the selected option instead of "Windows XP". 
- The dropdown menu listing screen saver options is expanded, revealing choices like "3D FlowerBox", "3D Flying Objects", "My Pictures Slideshow", etc.

The screenshot displays the "Display Properties" window in Windows XP, specifically the "Screen Saver" tab. 

The "Screen Saver" dropdown menu is currently open, displaying a list of available screen savers. The option "None" is highlighted, indicating it is selected as the active screen saver. 

Three buttons are visible to the right of the screen saver selection area:

* **Settings:** Currently inactive (greyed out), this button would allow for adjustments to the chosen screen saver's settings.
* **Preview:** Also inactive, this button would typically initiate a preview of the selected screen saver within the monitor graphic above.
* **Power...:** This active button, when clicked, opens the "Power Options Properties" window for managing power settings.

At the bottom of the window, two standard buttons are present:

* **Apply:** Currently inactive, this button would apply any changes made within the "Display Properties" window.
* **Cancel:** This active button allows the user to close the "Display Properties" window without saving any changes made.

The screenshot shows the "Display Properties" window in the foreground, with the "Screen Saver" tab selected. A new window, titled "Power Options Properties", is now visible, partially obscuring the "Display Properties" window.

The screenshot shows the "Display Properties" window in the foreground, with the "Screen Saver" tab selected.  A new window, "Power Options Properties" is open on top and obscures a portion of the "Display Properties" window. The "Power Options Properties" window is in focus.

The screenshot displays the "Display Properties" window in Windows XP, specifically the "Screen Saver" tab. 

The "Screen saver" dropdown menu is set to "[None]", disabling the screen saver feature. Below, a text box labeled "Wait" allows users to specify the idle time in minutes before the screen saver activates, although it's currently irrelevant as the screen saver is disabled. The "On resume, password protect" checkbox, if enabled, would require a password to exit the screen saver, but this option is also currently inactive due to the disabled screen saver.

The "Monitor power" section provides instructions to click the "Power" button for adjusting monitor power settings. The "Power" button itself is highlighted, indicating the user is about to click it to open the "Power Options Properties" window for further power management configuration.

The screenshot shows two windows: "Display Properties" and "Power Options Properties". 

New UI Elements:
- The "Power Options Properties" window is now visible. This window contains:
    - A title bar with the title "Power Options Properties" and standard window controls.
    - A dropdown menu labeled "Power schemes" currently displaying "Home/Office Desk".
    - Buttons labeled "Save As..." and "Delete".
    - A text box labeled "Turn off monitor:" showing "After 20 mins".
    - A text box labeled "Turn off hard disks:" 

Missing UI Elements:
- The "Screen Saver" tab content from the "Display Properties" window is no longer visible.
- The "Power" button in the "Display Properties" window is no longer highlighted. 

Content Changes:
- The "Display Properties" window title bar now shows "Display Properties" and "Power Options Properties", indicating it's behind the active "Power Options Properties" window.

The screenshot shows the "Power Options Properties" window overlaid on top of the "Display Properties" window. 

New UI Elements:
- The "Power Options Properties" window is now visible. This window has tabs titled: "Power Schemes", "Advanced", "Hibernate", and "UPS". 
- The "Power Schemes" tab is currently selected. 
- A dropdown menu labeled "Power schemes" is set to "Home/Office Desk". 
- Below the dropdown, there are four settings for the "Home/Office Desk power scheme": 
    - "Turn off monitor" is set to "After 20 mins".
    - "Turn off hard disks" is set to "Never".
    - "System standby" is set to "Never".
    - "System hibernates" is set to "Never". 

Content Changes:
- The "Power" button from the "Display Properties" window is no longer highlighted.

The screenshot displays the "Power Options Properties" window in Windows XP. 

The **"Power Schemes" tab** is currently selected, indicating the user is customizing a power plan. 

A dropdown menu labeled **"Power schemes"** shows the currently active power scheme as "Home/Office Desk". 

Below, the **"Settings for Home/Office Desk power scheme"** section lists power-saving options:
* **"Turn off monitor"** is set to "After 20 mins" using a dropdown menu.
* **"Turn off hard disks"**, **"System standby"**, and **"System hibernate"** are all set to "Never" using individual dropdown menus.

At the bottom of the window, three buttons offer actions: 
* **"OK"**: Confirms changes and closes the window.
* **"Cancel"**: Closes the window without saving any changes. 
* **"Apply"**: Applies the current settings without closing the window.

The screenshot shows the "Power Options Properties" window with the "Power Schemes" tab selected. The "Home/Office Desk" power scheme is currently active. 

The following content changes are visible:

* **"Turn off monitor"** is expanded, showing a dropdown menu with options: "After 20 mins", "After 25 mins", "After 30 mins", "After 45 mins", "After 1 hour", "After 2 hours", "After 3 hours", "After 4 hours" and "After 5 hours". 
* **"Turn off hard disks"** is expanded, showing a dropdown menu with options: "After 10 mins", "After 15 mins", "After 20 mins", "After 30 mins", "After 45 mins", "After 1 hour", "After 2 hours", "After 3 hours", "After 4 hours" and "After 5 hours". 
* **"System standby"** is expanded, showing a dropdown menu with options: "After 10 mins", "After 15 mins", "After 20 mins", "After 30 mins", "After 45 mins", "After 1 hour", "After 2 hours", "After 3 hours", "After 4 hours" and "After 5 hours". 
* **"System hibernates"** is expanded, showing a dropdown menu with options: "After 10 mins", "After 15 mins", "After 20 mins", "After 30 mins", "After 45 mins", "After 1 hour", "After 2 hours", "After 3 hours", "After 4 hours" and "After 5 hours".

The screenshot shows the "Power Options Properties" window with the "Turn off monitor" dropdown menu expanded, revealing a list of time intervals ranging from "After 3 mins" to "Never". 

- **Content Changes**: 
    - The "Turn off monitor" dropdown menu is now expanded and displaying its options.

The screenshot shows the "Power Options Properties" window with the "Power Schemes" tab selected. The "Home/Office Desk" power scheme is currently active. 

The dropdown menus for "Turn off monitor", "Turn off hard disks", "System standby", and "System hibernate" are now expanded, displaying a list of time options. The "Turn off monitor" dropdown is selected to "After 20 mins".

The screenshot displays the "Power Options Properties" window in the Windows XP Control Panel. 

The "Power Schemes" tab is active, and the "Home/Office Desk" power scheme is currently selected. This scheme manages power settings like monitor and hard disk shut off, standby, and hibernation.

Four dropdown menus are visible, each controlling a specific power setting:
- **"Turn off monitor"**: Controls the duration of inactivity before the monitor turns off.
- **"Turn off hard disks"**:  Controls the duration of inactivity before the hard disk turns off.
- **"System standby"**: Controls the duration of inactivity before the system enters standby mode.
- **"System hibernates"**: Controls the duration of inactivity before the system enters hibernation mode.

The "System hibernates" dropdown menu is currently expanded, displaying the option "Never" selected by the user. This setting, when applied, would prevent the system from automatically entering hibernation mode. 

Other visible elements include:
- **"Save As" button**: Allows users to save the current settings as a new power scheme with a custom name.
- **"Delete" button**: Allows users to delete the currently selected power scheme. This button is greyed out, indicating it's inactive for the default "Home/Office Desk" scheme.

The screenshot shows the "Power Options Properties" window, with the "Power Schemes" tab selected. The "Home/Office Desk" power scheme is active. 

Content Changes:
- The dropdowns for "Turn off monitor", "Turn off hard disks", "System standby", and "System hibernates" all now display "Never".

The screenshot displays the "Power Options Properties" window in Windows XP. 

The "Power Schemes" tab is active, showing the "Home/Office Desk" power scheme currently selected.  This scheme's settings are displayed in the "Settings for Home/Office Desk power scheme" section.  

Within this section, four dropdown menus are visible: 
- **"Turn off monitor"**:  Currently set to "Never".
- **"Turn off hard disks"**: Currently set to "Never".
- **"System standby"**: Currently set to "Never".
- **"System hibernates"**: Currently set to "Never". 

At the bottom of the window, three buttons are enabled:
- **OK**: Clicking this button will apply any changes made within the window and close the window. 
- **Cancel**: Clicking this button will close the window without saving any changes.
- **Apply**: Clicking this button will apply any changes made within the window, keeping the window open.

The screenshot shows the "Power Options Properties" window with the "Home/Office Desk" power scheme selected. The "Always On" power scheme is now visible in the list of available power schemes. All four dropdown menus: "Turn off monitor", "Turn off hard disks", "System standby", and "System hibernates" are still set to "Never".

The screenshot shows the "Power Options Properties" window with the "Power Schemes" tab selected. The "Home/Office Desk" power scheme is currently selected. 

The following elements have changed:

- **Content Change**: The dropdown menu for "Turn off monitor" is now set to "Never".
- **Content Change**: The dropdown menu for "Turn off hard disks" is now set to "Never".
- **Content Change**: The dropdown menu for "System standby" is now set to "Never".
- **Content Change**: The dropdown menu for "System hibernates" is now set to "Never".

The screenshot shows the "Power Options Properties" window with the "Power Schemes" tab selected. The "Always On" power scheme is highlighted in the "Power schemes" dropdown menu. The "Settings for Always On power scheme" section displays the following:

- **"Turn off monitor"**: Set to "Never".
- **"Turn off hard disks"**: Set to "Never".
- **"System standby"**: Set to "Never".
- **"System hibernates"**: Set to "Never".

Content Changes:

- The "Power schemes" dropdown menu now displays "Always On" as the selected scheme instead of "Home/Office Desk".

The screenshot displays the "Power Options Properties" window in Windows XP. 

The "Power Schemes" tab is active, presenting a dropdown menu labeled "Power schemes" with the "Always On" scheme currently selected. This selection determines the active power management settings displayed below.

Four system power settings are shown, each with a corresponding dropdown menu to adjust its value:

* **Turn off monitor:**  Set to "Never". Controls the time delay before the monitor is automatically turned off.
* **Turn off hard disks:** Set to "Never". Controls the time delay before the hard drive is automatically powered down.
* **System standby:** Set to "Never". Controls the time delay before the computer enters standby mode.
* **System hibernates:** Set to "Never". Controls the time delay before the computer enters hibernation mode.

At the bottom of the window, three buttons provide the following actions:

* **OK:** Closes the window and applies any changes made to the power settings.
* **Cancel:** Closes the window without saving any changes.
* **Apply:** Applies any changes made to the power settings without closing the window.

The screenshot shows the "Power Options Properties" window with the "Power Schemes" tab active. The "Always On" power scheme is selected.

The following system power settings are all set to "Never":
- Turn off monitor
- Turn off hard disks
- System standby
- System hibernates 

No new UI elements are present. No UI elements are missing.

The "Power Options Properties" window is open and displaying the "Power Schemes" tab.  The "Always On" power scheme is currently selected in the "Power schemes" dropdown menu. This menu allows users to choose from a list of pre-configured power plans. 

Below, the "Settings for Always On power scheme" section displays four adjustable power management options:

- **"Turn off monitor"**:  This dropdown menu, currently set to "After 20 mins," controls the time delay before the monitor enters power saving mode. 
- **"Turn off hard disks:"** This dropdown menu, currently set to "Never," controls the time delay before the hard drive enters power saving mode. 
- **"System standby:"** This dropdown menu, currently set to "Never," controls the time delay before the computer enters standby mode. 
- **"System hibernates:"** This dropdown menu, currently set to "Never," controls the time delay before the computer enters hibernation mode.

At the bottom of the window, three buttons offer options for managing the power scheme settings:

- **"OK"**: Clicking this button applies any changes made and closes the window.
- **"Cancel"**: Clicking this button discards any changes made and closes the window.
- **"Apply"**:  Clicking this button applies any changes made to the power scheme settings without closing the window.

The screenshot displays the "Power Options Properties" window in Windows XP. 

The "Always On" power scheme is currently selected in the "Power schemes" dropdown menu. This menu allows users to choose from pre-set or custom power plans. 

The "Settings for 'Always On' power scheme" section displays four configurable power management options:

* **Turn off monitor:** This dropdown menu, currently set to "After 20 mins," allows the user to define after what duration of inactivity the monitor should turn off.
* **Turn off hard disks:** This dropdown menu, currently set to "Never," allows the user to define after what duration of inactivity the hard disk should turn off.
* **System standby:** This dropdown menu, currently set to "Never," allows the user to define after what duration of inactivity the system should enter standby mode.
* **System hibernates:** This dropdown menu, currently set to "Never," allows the user to define after what duration of inactivity the system should hibernate.

At the bottom of the window, there are three buttons:

* **OK:** Clicking this button would apply any changes made and close the window.
* **Cancel:** Clicking this button would discard any changes made and close the window.
* **Apply:** Clicking this button would apply any changes made without closing the window.

The screenshot shows the "Power Options Properties" window in Windows XP. The "Always On" power scheme is selected. The dropdown menus for "Turn off monitor", "Turn off hard disks", "System standby", and "System hibernates" are all expanded, displaying the available time options.
The screenshot shows the "Power Options Properties" window in Windows XP. The "Turn off monitor" dropdown menu is expanded and the user is hovering over the "After 20 mins" option.

The screenshot shows the "Power Options Properties" window with the "Turn off monitor" dropdown menu expanded, revealing a list of time intervals ranging from "After 1 min" to "Never". 

Content Changes:
- The "Turn off monitor" dropdown menu is now expanded and showing the available options.

The screenshot shows the "Power Options Properties" window in Windows XP, with the "Power Schemes" tab active. 

The "Power schemes" dropdown menu displays "Always On" as the currently selected power scheme.  Below, four power management settings are shown: "Turn off monitor", "Turn off hard disks", "System standby", and "System hibernates". Each setting has a dropdown menu currently displaying a range of time intervals from "After 1 min" to "After 5 hours", with the "Never" option visible at the bottom of the expanded "System hibernates" dropdown menu. 

Three buttons are available to the right of the "Power schemes" dropdown: 
- "Save As...": Allows the user to create a new power scheme based on the current settings. 
- "Delete": Allows the user to delete a custom power scheme. This button is greyed out, indicating it is currently inactive.

The screenshot shows the "Power Options Properties" window with the "Always On" power scheme selected. The "Turn off monitor" dropdown menu now displays "After 20 mins".  The "Turn off hard disks", "System standby", and "System hibernates" dropdown menus all now display "Never".

The screenshot displays the "Power Options Properties" window in Windows XP. The "Always On" power scheme is currently selected in the "Power schemes" dropdown menu. 

The "Settings for 'Always On' power scheme" section allows the user to configure when the monitor, hard disks, system standby, and system hibernate are activated. Each setting features a dropdown menu, currently set to "Never," indicating that these power-saving features will not engage automatically.

At the bottom of the window, three buttons offer different actions:

* **OK:** Clicking this button would apply any changes made to the power scheme and close the window.
* **Cancel:** This button is highlighted, indicating the user's current selection. Clicking it would close the window without saving any changes made within the "Power Options Properties" window.
* **Apply:** This button would apply any changes made to the power scheme without closing the window.

The screenshot shows the "Power Options Properties" window with the "Cancel" button highlighted. 

The following changes are observed:

- The "OK" button is no longer highlighted.

The screenshot shows the "Display Properties" window in Windows XP, with the "Appearance and Themes" category visible in the background. 

The "Power Options Properties" window is no longer present.

The screenshot shows the "Appearance and Themes" window open in the Windows XP Control Panel. The "Display Properties" window is also open and is the active window, indicated by the blue title bar. 

Missing UI Elements:
- The "Power Options Properties" window is no longer present.

The screenshot shows the "Display Properties" window in Windows XP, with the "Screen Saver" tab active. The "Power Options Properties" window is not present. 
- The previously highlighted "Cancel" button in the "Power Options Properties" window is no longer visible. 
- The "Appearance and Themes" window is visible behind the "Display Properties" window. 
- The mouse cursor is hovering over the "Appearance and The..." button on the taskbar.

The screenshot shows the "Display Properties" window in Windows XP, specifically the "Screen Saver" tab. 

The "Power Options Properties" window is no longer present. 

The previously highlighted "Cancel" button in the "Power Options Properties" window is no longer highlighted as the window itself is closed.

The screenshot displays the "Display Properties" window in Windows XP, specifically the "Screen Saver" tab. 

The "Screen saver" dropdown menu shows "[None]" selected, disabling the screen saver feature. Below, a numerical field labeled "Wait:" is set to "10" minutes, representing the idle time before the screen saver would activate (if one was chosen). The "On resume, password protect" checkbox is unchecked, indicating that a password would not be required to exit the screen saver. 

The "Monitor power" section provides a brief instruction: "To adjust monitor power settings and save energy, click Power."  This section also features a "Power…" button, which presumably opens a separate window for managing power settings. 

At the bottom of the window, several buttons are visible:
- "OK": Currently highlighted, suggesting user interaction. This button likely confirms changes and closes the window.
- "Cancel":  This button likely discards any changes and closes the window.
- "Apply": This button likely applies any changes without closing the window.

The screenshot shows the "Display Properties" window, specifically the "Screen Saver" tab. The most noticeable change is the mouse cursor, now an arrow with a blue circle beneath it, hovering over the "OK" button at the bottom of the window.  The "OK" button is also highlighted.

The screenshot shows the "Appearance and Themes" window within the Windows XP Control Panel. 

Missing UI Elements:
- The "Display Properties" window, specifically the "Screen Saver" tab, is no longer present. 

New UI Elements:
- The "Appearance and Themes" window is now visible, displaying various customization options.

The screenshot displays the "Appearance and Themes" category within the Windows XP Control Panel.  The window is framed with the standard title bar, featuring the minimize, maximize/restore, and close buttons on the top right. 

The main area of the window is divided into three sections:

1. **"See Also"**: This section, located on the left side, provides quick access to related system tasks, including "Fonts," "Mouse Pointers," "High Contrast," and "User Account Picture."

2. **"Troubleshooters"**: Situated below "See Also," this section offers troubleshooting options for "Display" and "Sound" issues.

3. **"Pick a task..."**: This central section dominates the window and presents a list of common customization options: "Change the computer's theme," "Change the desktop background," "Choose a screen saver," and "Change the screen resolution."

4. **"or pick a Control Panel icon"**: Located below the "Pick a task..." section, this area provides shortcuts to directly access the "Display" and "Folder Options" settings. 

The user can navigate these options using the mouse to click on the desired task or icon.
